State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering Tianjin University Tianjin 300350 China Graphical abstract Acidic ionic liquids were employed to catalyze the hydrolysis of methyl acetate. The optimal ionic liquid catalyst 1-butylsulfonic-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate ([BSO3HMIm][OTf]) was selected from four Brönsted acidic ionic liquids. The reaction kinetics and chemical equilibrium of hydrolysis reaction catalyzed by [BSO3HMIm][OTf] were investigated. The hydrolysis mechanism catalyzed by [BSO3HMIm][OTf] was proposed, and non-ideal pseudo-homogeneous (NIPH) model was derived based on the hydrolysis mechanism. The hydrolysis reaction with mixed ionic liquids as catalyst and solvent was also conducted. The influence of solvent 1-octyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium bis((trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl)imide ([OMMIm][Tf2N]) on the reaction rate was investigated. The chemical-phase equilibrium (CPE) was measured to investigate the effects of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] and [OMMIm][Tf2N] on chemical equilibrium and vapor-liquid equilibrium of the reaction mixture. The results show that chemical equilibrium constant is not affected by IL catalyst and solvent, but the vapor-liquid equilibrium is significantly influenced by IL solvent. Keywords Hydrolysis Methyl acetate Ionic liquid Catalyst Solvent 1 Introduction Ionic liquids (ILs), consisting of ions [1,2], have recently been widely used in reaction, separation, electrochemistry, etc. [3–7], owing to their visible advantages of high catalytic activity, versatile designability, low melting point, high conductivity, negligible vapor pressure, easy recyclability and so on [6–13]. Since ILs are highly tunable, ILs catalysts can meet the specifications of a chemical process by appropriately selecting the cations and anions [14–16]. Acidic ionic liquids (AILs) have gained much attention as green catalysts in various reactions [15,17–20]. Guo et al. conducted etherification reaction in AILs and demonstrated that AILs exhibited higher selectivity than sulfuric acid [21]. Gui and co-workers also found that Brönsted acidic ionic liquids (BAILs) could effectively catalyze esterification reaction of acetic acid and ethanol with high selectivity [22]. Tao et al. prepared noncorrosive BAILs to perform liquid-liquid catalysis of esterification [16]. Wei and co-workers studied Fischer esterification using BAILs as solvent and catalyst [23]. Besides, Xie et al. conducted the synthesis of plasticizer ester employed HSO3-functionalized AILs which exhibited higher activity than non-functionalized AILs, and the conversion of acid (reactant) was not less than 95% when ionic liquids were reused at least six times [24]. Furthermore, Yang et al. reported transesterification kinetics with HSO3-functionalized IL as catalyst, and proposed the transesterification mechanism [25]. Jie et al. used HSO3-functionalized IL catalyst to efficiently produce isobutyl acetate by transesterification [26]. Peng and co-authors measured the reaction kinetics of transesterification catalyzed by 1-butylsulfonic-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate ([BSO3HMIm][OTf]) [27]. Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), which can be converted into multitudinous chemical products, is versatile and essential. The inevitable by-product methyl acetate (MeOAc) in the industrial synthesis process of PVA has limited commercial uses [28]. Hence, it is essential to convert MeOAc into more valuable methanol (MeOH) and acetic acid (HAc) as feedstocks for the synthesis of PVA [28]. However, chemical equilibrium of hydrolysis limits the conversion of MeOAc. Reactive distillation (RD) can greatly improve the conversion of MeOAc in hydrolysis process [29]. Currently, the catalyst used in the industrial process of hydrolysis of MeOAc in RD process is ion exchange resin. However, its thermal stability is low, the installation of the catalyst in the RD column is complicated, and it will swell and cause diffusion problems [16,30]. To overcome the shortcomings of ion exchange resin in the catalytic hydrolysis of MeOAc, BAILs are promising catalysts. Moreover, the reaction kinetic data are vital for RD process. Mekala and Goli have compared the reaction kinetics of the esterification of HAc with MeOH under homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts and demonstrated that liquid catalyst was better than heterogeneous catalysts [31]. The reaction kinetics of hydrolysis of MeOAc catalyzed by mineral acid, acetic acid and ion exchange resin is measured [32–34]. Tao and co-workers have investigated the reverse reaction of hydrolysis (the esterification of HAc with MeOH) using BAILs as catalysts for their low corrosive feature and high catalytic activity [35]. However, the hydrolysis of MeOAc catalyzed by BAILs has not been found in the open literatures. For hydrolysis of MeOAc in a RD column, MeOAc forms binary azeotropic mixture with MeOH and the conversion of MeOAc is limited by the azeotrope. Reactive and extractive distillation (RED) is an effective process for equilibrium reactions with azeotropes. Jie et al. conducted transesterification in RED process to enhance conversions of reactants and selected molecular liquid solvent to destroy azeotropic mixture [26]. If a RED column is used in hydrolysis reaction, the azeotrope of MeOAc and MeOH will be destroyed by a solvent which can make MeOH more volatile, so that the conversion of MeOAc will be greatly increased, which can even be totally converted theoretically. Shang et al. found that IL 1-octyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium bis((trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl)imide ([OMMIm][Tf2N]) could effectively destroy the azeotrope of MeOAc and MeOH and make MeOH more volatile [36]. Furthermore, IL catalyst influences the phase equilibrium of reaction system. Jie and co-workers investigated the influence of IL catalyst on the vapor-liquid equilibrium of a transesterification system [26]. However, the influences of mixed IL solvent and catalyst on chemical-phase equilibrium are not found in the published literatures. In this work, four HSO3-functionalized acidic imidazolium-ILs were used to catalyze the hydrolysis of MeOAc, then the optimal IL catalyst was selected. Reaction kinetics of hydrolysis of MeOAc was measured using [BSO3HMIm][OTf] as catalyst. The hydrolysis mechanism of MeOAc catalyzed by AILs was proposed, and a reaction rate model was derived base on the reaction mechanism. The effect of IL solvent [OMMIm][Tf2N] on the hydrolysis reaction was also studied. The chemical equilibrium and vapor-liquid equilibrium of the hydrolysis reaction mixture with IL catalyst and solvent were studied. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals MeOAc (≥99.0 wt %, Aladdin), MeOH (≥99.8 wt %, Chemart), HAc (≥99.8 wt %, Chemart) and ILs (≥99.0 wt %, Aolike) were used without further treatment and purification. The water content in chemicals was confirmed by Karl Fischer titration (KFT) and mass fraction of water was less than 0.0002. 2.2 Experimental methods To carry out reaction kinetics, a four-neck round bottom flask (100 mL) was employed with a calibrated thermometer (accuracy ± 0.01 K) to measure the reaction temperature, as detailed in our previous study [37]. All samples were taken with a syringe at predetermined intervals. IL catalyst concentrations were between 0.10 and 0.30 mol·L−1, reaction temperatures were 313.15, 318.15, 323.15 and 328.15 K and initial molar ratios of water to MeOAc were 0.5, 1.0, 1.5, 2.0, 2.5 and 3.0. The agitation speeds were between 100 and 300 rpm. The experiments of chemical-phase equilibrium (chemical and vapor-liquid equilibrium) of the reaction system were performed in an all glass dynamic recirculating still at 101.3 kPa, which is usually utilized to measure vapor-liquid equilibrium data as described in our previous works [38,39]. In the process of measurements, the vapor and liquid phase samples were taken every 30 min and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) which was at the same conditions as reaction kinetics experiments. The initial reactant molar ratio of water to MeOAc was 1.5. Mole fraction of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] was 0.05-0.15 and mole fraction of [OMMIm][Tf2N] was 0.30-0.50. 2.3 Analysis For reaction kinetics experiments, all samples were analyzed by GC as described in our literature [36]. The temperatures of column, injector, and detector were 343.15, 423.15 and 443.15 K, respectively. In reaction kinetics experiments, the mole fractions of water, MeOAc, MeOH, HAc in reaction mixture can be computed by conversion of MeOAc which is calculated from the data obtained by GC, the detailed method is in the Supporting Information (SI). For chemical-phase equilibrium experiments, since the boiling points of ILs are very high, no ionic liquids exist in vapor phase. The vapor phase samples were also analyzed by GC using internal standard method with tetrahydrofuran as internal standard, as illustrated in our previous work [40], and water content was confirmed by Karl Fischer titration. The liquid phase samples were analyzed by the same method as that used in reaction kinetics experiments. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Selection of BAILs catalysts BAILs have much weaker corrosiveness than H2SO4 and they exhibit good catalytic activity for many reactions [18,41]. Herein, BAILs 1-sulfopropyl-3-methylimidazolium hydrosulfate ([PrSO3HMIm][HSO4]), 1-sulfobutyl-3-methylimidazolium hydrosulfate ([BSO3HMIm][HSO4]), [BSO3HMIm][OTf] and 1-sulfobutyl-3-methylimidazolium chloride ([BSO3HMIm][Cl]) were used to catalyze the hydrolysis of MeOAc. The structures of the ILs are shown in Fig. 1 . To compare the catalytic activity of BAILs, the basic reaction conditions were set: reaction temperature was 323.15 K, catalyst concentration was 0.2 mol·L−1, initial molar ratio of water to MeOAc was 1.5, and agitation speed was 200 rpm. The acidic ionic liquid catalysts were tested at basic reaction conditions. Fig. 2 shows the results. The catalytic activity of ILs is in a decreasing order of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] > [PrSO3HMIm][HSO4] > [BSO3HMIm][HSO4] > [BSO3HMIm][Cl]. Generally, reaction rate relies on the acidity of IL catalyst [42]. However, MeOAc is partial soluble with water at the initial state of the reaction, and ILs catalysts are more soluble in water phase, so the hydrolysis reaction rate is also affected by the solubility of catalysts in methyl acetate phase. After some methanol and acetic acid are produced, the reaction mixture will change to one phase. [BSO3HMIm][Cl] has the slowest reaction rate because of its lowest acidity and poorest solubility in MeOAc [43–48]. Acidity of [PrSO3HMIm][HSO4] is greater than that of [BSO3HMIm][HSO4] [48], so hydrolysis reaction rate of MeOAc catalyzed by [PrSO3HMIm][HSO4] is higher. However, the hydrolysis reaction rate using [BSO3HMIm][OTf] as a catalyst is higher than using [PrSO3HMIm][HSO4] and [BSO3Hmim][HSO4], because the solubility of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] in MeOAc is larger than that of [PrSO3HMIm][HSO4] and [BSO3Hmim][HSO4], though the acidity of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] is less than that of [PrSO3HMIm][HSO4] and [BSO3Hmim][HSO4] [45,46,48]. 3.2 Catalytic reaction kinetics As described in the above section, the optimal catalyst for the hydrolysis of methyl acetate is [BSO3HMIm][OTf], so we utilized [BSO3HMIm][OTf] to measure the reaction kinetics in the following sections. We evaluated the influence of agitation (100−300 rpm) and found agitation speed has no evident effect on reaction rate (for details see Fig. S1 in SI), so agitation speed was 200 rpm in following kinetics experiments. Fig. 3 illustrates the effects of catalyst concentration, temperature, and initial molar ratio of reactants on the conversion of MeOAc. In this figure, the slopes of the curves are proportional to reaction rates (see section 3.4), so the curves also reflect the reaction rates. Fig. 3 (a) reveals that the conversion of MeOAc and reaction rate increase significantly with increasing IL catalyst concentration at the early stage of the reaction. The reaction time to reach chemical equilibrium is reduced with increasing catalyst concentration, but the equilibrium conversion is not affected by catalyst concentration. The effect of reaction temperature is shown in Fig. 3 (b). It indicates that in the same reaction time, with increasing temperature, reaction rate increases obviously but equilibrium conversion increases slightly, because the hydrolysis reaction is endothermic, but the reaction enthalpy is small (see section 3.3). The initial molar ratio of water to MeOAc ( R W / M 0 ) also affects the hydrolysis reaction. Fig. 3 (c) illustrates that the equilibrium conversion and reaction rate both increase with R W / M 0 . Since the hydrolysis is limited by chemical equilibrium, the excess of water increases the conversion of MeOAc and equilibrium shifts to the product side. The initial reaction rate is useful for investigating the reaction kinetics. The dependence of the initial reaction rate on IL concentration was investigated to explore the relationship between reaction rate and IL catalyst concentration, as shown in Eq. (1). The parameters in Eq. (1), E and F, were fitted by experimental results. The fitted value of E and F is 0.3081 min−1 and 1.0, respectively. The results are illustrated in Fig. 4 . The mean squared error is 1.028 × 10-6. (1) r 0 = 1 ν i d c i d t t = 0 = E c c a t F where  r 0 is the initial reaction rate, mol·L−1 min−1; v is the stoichiometric coefficient; c is the molar concentration, mol·L−1; ccat is the molar concentration of IL catalyst, mol·L−1; and i is the i th component. 3.3 Chemical equilibrium The hydrolysis reaction of MeOAc is a reversible reaction, so the chemical equilibrium was measured. At basic reaction conditions, experiments were performed at 313.15, 318.15, 323.15 and 328.15 K to calculate chemical equilibrium constant(Ka ) in terms of activities according to Eq. (2): (2) K a ( T ) = α M e O H α H A c α M e O A c α w a t e r e q = x M e O H x H A c x M e O A c x w a t e r e q γ M e O H γ H A c γ M e O A c γ w a t e r e q Where α is the activity; x represents the mole fraction; γ represents the activity coefficient. The activity coefficients were calculated by NRTL model (see SI, all NRTL parameters are listed in Table S1). Generally, assuming the standard enthalpy of reaction (Δ rH 0) to be constant due to small temperature variation range, the relationship between Ka and temperature (T) can be calculated by integrating the van’t Hoff equation as following: (3) ln K a ( T ) = ln K a ( T 0 ) − Δ r H 0 R 1 T − 1 T 0 Therefore, Δ rH 0 can be calculated from the slope of lnKa to 1/T. According to experimental data, we obtained the equilibrium constants at 313.15, 318.15, 323.15 and 328.15 K. The linear relationship between lnKa and 1/T was illustrated in Fig. 5 , and Eq. (4) was obtained to express the temperature dependence of equilibrium constant: (4) ln K a = − 1.3035 − 612.4 T The Δ rH 0 calculated from experimental data as well as that calculated from the standard enthalpy of formation (Δ fH 0, listed in Table 1 ) is shown in Table 2 , which indicates that the hydrolysis of MeOAc is an endothermic reaction. Since the standard enthalpy of the hydrolysis reaction is small, the temperature has a little influence on chemical equilibrium constant. 3.4 Catalytic mechanism and kinetic model For hydrolysis of methyl acetate in ionic liquid, catalytic reaction mechanism has been proposed (shown in Fig. 6 ). Generally, the catalytic hydrolysis reaction in ionic liquid involves two main processes: the formation of carbocation (step 1) and the formation of hydrolysis products (step 2). Step 2 is rate-controlled step since step 1 is very quick and assumed to be in equilibrium [49,50]. A non-ideal pseudo-homogeneous (NIPH) model can describe the reaction rate properly (see SI). (5) NIPH model : r = 1 V 1 ν i d n i d t = c c a t ρ 2 k + α M e O A c α w a t e r − k − α M e O H α H A c where r represents the reaction rate, V represents the volume of reaction mixture, n represents the number of moles of a component and ρ represents the molar density of reaction mixture. The k+ and k− represent forward and backward reaction rate constants which can be described by Arrhenius equation: (6) k = A exp − E R T where A and E are pre-exponential factor and activation energy for reaction, respectively; R is the gas constant, 8.314 J·mol−1 K−1; T is the temperature, K. If the activity of each component in Eq. (5) is replaced by mole fraction, the NIPH is simplified to IPH model. About 300 kinetic data points were correlated by minimizing mean relative deviation (MRD) using the two models. The MRD of NIPH model is less than that of IPH model (0.0265 for NIPH, 0.0323 for IPH, see SI for details), which indicates that NIPH model is suitable for describing the hydrolysis reaction rate. Reaction rate expressed by NIPH model is showed in Eq. (8). The conversion XMeOAc was calculated by the following equation: (9) d X M e O A c d t = r M e O A c ρ x M e O A c 0 The curves in Fig. 3 (a), Fig. 3 (b), and Fig. 3 (c) are the calculated results by the integration of Eq. (9). It can be seen from the figures that NIPH model can well describe the reaction kinetics of hydrolysis of MeOAc. 3.5 Effect of [OMMIm][Tf2N] on hydrolysis reaction kinetics Shang et al. investigated the effect of [OMMIm][Tf2N] on the isobaric vapor-liquid equilibrium for MeOAc + MeOH and found that [OMMIm][Tf2N] was effective to enhance the relative volatility of MeOH to MeOAc [36]. The azeotropic point of MeOH and MeOAc can be eliminated by [OMMIm][Tf2N], and MeOH is the volatile component. IL [OMMIm][Tf2N] is a promising solvent for the reactive and extractive distillation process by which the hydrolysis of MeOAc can be effectively conducted. To explore the influence of solvent [OMMIm][Tf2N] on the hydrolysis reaction, we conducted experiments at basic reaction conditions using mixed ILs ([BSO3HMIm][OTf] + [OMMIm][Tf2N]), with the molar ratios of [OMMIm][Tf2N] to [BSO3HMIm][OTf] (R) 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0. It should be noted that [OMMIm][Tf2N] does not provide H+, so the solvent cannot catalyze the hydrolysis reaction. As shown in Fig. 7 , when we used mixed ILs as catalyst and solvent, the reaction rate decreased slightly with the increase of [OMMIm][Tf2N], because the catalyst was diluted by the solvent. The larger the molar ratio of [OMMIm][Tf2N] to [BSO3HMIm][OTf] is, the lower the [BSO3HMIm][OTf] concentration is in reaction mixture, so that the slower the reaction rate is. 3.6 Effects of ionic liquid catalyst and solvent on chemical-phase equilibrium Generally, reversible reaction is often carried out in a RD column, or a RED column, and the reaction mixture is in vapor-liquid equilibrium, so the chemical-phase equilibrium (CPE) of the reaction mixture is essential to the operation and design of such columns. The chemical-phase equilibrium for reaction mixture means that reaction mixture reaches both chemical equilibrium and phase equilibrium (herein, vapor-liquid equilibrium). We investigated the effects of ionic liquid catalyst [BSO3HMIm][OTf] and solvent [OMMIm][Tf2N] on the chemical-phase equilibrium for the hydrolysis of MeOAc. The mole fraction of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] in the experiments was in the range of 0.05 to 0.15, and the mole fraction of [OMMIm][Tf2N] was in the range of 0.3 to 0.5. The results of chemical-phase equilibria are shown in Fig. 8 . The mole fractions of reactants and products are on a IL excluding basis, x IL means the mole fraction of IL, x is the mole fraction of a component in liquid phase and y is the mole fraction of a component in vapor phase. As can be seen from Fig. 8 (a), IL catalyst [BSO3HMIm][OTf] has a little effect on the chemical-phase equilibrium. To further investigate the effect of the catalyst on the azeotrope of MeOAc + MeOH, we used COSMO-SAC model to predict phase equilibrium data for the mixture in the presence of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] (as showed in Fig. 9 ). Fig. 9 indicates that [BSO3HMIm][OTf] makes the reactant methyl acetate more volatile. Fig. 8 (b) shows that [OMMIm][Tf2N] has a little effect on the liquid composition of the reaction mixture, but it has significant influences on the mole fractions of MeOAc and MeOH in vapor phase. When the concentration of [OMMIm][Tf2N] increases in reaction mixture, the equilibrium temperature increases a little, but the enthalpy of reaction is small, so the compositions of the liquid phase (reaction mixture) only change a little. IL [OMMIm][Tf2N] can increase the relative volatility of MeOH to MeOAc and the relative volatility increases with the amount of [OMMIm][Tf2N] in liquid phase [36], therefore, in the vapor phase, the mole fraction of MeOH increases and that of MeOAc decreases with the increasing concentration of [OMMIm][Tf2N] as shown in Fig. 8(b). Fig. 8 also indicates that the mole fraction of HAc is greater than that of methanol in liquid phase. If only methyl acetate and water is added in initial reaction mixture, and reaction is conducted in a temperature below the boiling point of reaction mixture, the mole fractions of methanol and acetic acid are equal. However, when reaction mixture was in a chemical-phase equilibrium, the experiments were carried out in an equilibrium still at its boiling point, methanol is more volatile than acetic acid, so the mole fraction of methanol is much larger than that of HAc in vapor phase, and more methanol was condensed in vapor phase in the equilibrium still, therefore, in such cases, the mole fraction of methanol is less than that of acetic acid in liquid phase. Chemical equilibrium constants of chemical-phase equilibrium were obtained (as shown in Fig. 10 ). Fig. 10 indicates that the difference between the experimental chemical equilibrium constants and those calculated by Eq. (4) is very small, so the ionic liquids have no significant effects on the chemical equilibrium. Therefore, according to the discussion above, the chemical equilibrium constant is not affected by IL catalyst and solvent, but the vapor-liquid equilibrium can be significantly influenced by IL solvent. 4 Conclusions Four HSO3-functionalized acidic ILs were tested to catalyze the hydrolysis of MeOAc and ([BSO3HMIm][OTf]) has the highest catalytic activity. The reaction kinetics and chemical equilibrium of hydrolysis reaction catalyzed by [BSO3HMIm][OTf] were measured. Hydrolysis reaction rate increases with IL concentration, temperature and initial reactant molar ratio. The equilibrium conversion increases with initial molar ratio and temperature. NIPH kinetic model was proposed based on the hydrolysis mechanism to correlate kinetic data. The addition of IL solvent [OMMIm][Tf2N] has little effect on chemical equilibrium, but it results in a decrease of reaction rate. The effects of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] and [OMMIm][Tf2N] on chemical-phase equilibrium were studied. For the chemical-phase equilibrium, the chemical equilibrium constant is not affected by the IL catalyst and solvent, but the vapor-liquid equilibrium is significantly influenced by IL solvent. Ionic liquids [BSO3HMIm][OTf] and [OMMIm][Tf2N] are promising catalyst and solvent for the hydrolysis of MeOAc. coredata.dc:description: Acidic ionic liquids were employed to catalyze the hydrolysis of methyl acetate. The optimal ionic liquid catalyst 1-butylsulfonic-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate ([BSO3HMIm][OTf]) was selected from four Brönsted acidic ionic liquids. The reaction kinetics and chemical equilibrium of hydrolysis reaction catalyzed by [BSO3HMIm][OTf] were investigated. The hydrolysis mechanism catalyzed by [BSO3HMIm][OTf] was proposed, and non-ideal pseudo-homogeneous (NIPH) model was derived based on the hydrolysis mechanism. The hydrolysis reaction with mixed ionic liquids as catalyst and solvent was also conducted. The influence of solvent 1-octyl-2,3-dimethylimidazolium bis((trifluoromethyl)sulfonyl)imide ([OMMIm][Tf2N]) on the reaction rate was investigated. The chemical-phase equilibrium (CPE) was measured to investigate the effects of [BSO3HMIm][OTf] and [OMMIm][Tf2N] on chemical equilibrium and vapor-liquid equilibrium of the reaction mixture. The results show that chemical equilibrium constant is not affected by IL catalyst and solvent, but the vapor-liquid equilibrium is significantly influenced by IL solvent.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrolysis of methyl acetate using ionic liquids as catalyst and solvent
